#### 
‘Fanning The Flames’: Democrats Accuse Trump of Stoking Violence
----------------------------------------------------------------
 | August 30, 2020 5:17 pm
")
!Supporters of President Donald Trump and protesters hold banners as they wait for the motorcade of President Trump outside the Trump National Golf Club in Sterling, Va., Sunday, Aug. 30, 2020. (AP Photo / Manuel Balce Ceneta)
WASHINGTON (AP) — Democrats on Sunday accused President Donald Trump of trying to inflame racial tensions to benefit his campaign as he praised supporters who clashed with protesters in Portland, Oregon, where one man died overnight, and announced he will travel to Kenosha, Wisconsin, amid anger over the shooting of another Black man by police.
Thanks to our sponsors:
-----------------------
---------------------------------------------------
Trump’s tweets came hours after a man identified as a supporter of a right-wing group was shot and killed in Portland when a large caravan of Trump’s supporters and Black Lives Matter protesters clashed in the city’s streets. Trump praised the caravan participants as “GREAT PATRIOTS!” and blamed the city’s Democratic mayor for the death.
Trump has throughout the summer cast American cities as under siege by violence and lawlessness, despite the fact that most of the protests demonstrating against racial injustice have been largely peaceful. With about nine weeks until Election Day, some of his advisers see an aggressive “law and order” message as the best way for the president to turn voters against his Democratic rival, Joe Biden, and regain the support of suburban voters, particularly women, who have abandoned him. But Democrats accuse Trump of rooting for unrest and trying to stoke further violence for political gain instead of ratcheting down tensions.
Biden in a statement said he “unequivocally” condemned violence on all side, while accusing Trump of “recklessly encouraging” it...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: WTTW is the primary public media organization in Chicago. As a PBS affiliate, it is known for its commitment to factual reporting and journalistic integrity. The organization has a solid reputation in local news coverage, with a focus on accuracy, balanced reporting, and in-depth analysis. However, since it primarily covers regional stories, its scope may be limited for national news contexts.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: While the evidence discusses violence surrounding Trump supporters in the context of protests, it specifically mentions an incident in Portland, Oregon, rather than Chicago. It does help contextualize the atmosphere of violence during political protests but does not provide direct evidence regarding the claim in question.

metatags.twitter:title: Trump spars with reporters at Black journalists' conference over Kamala Harris' ethnicity, immigration and jobs
metatags.og:title: Trump spars with reporters at Black journalists' conference over Kamala Harris' ethnicity, immigration and jobs
metatags.twitter:description: Former President Donald Trump's appearance before the National Association of Black Journalists in Chicago quickly turned hostile on Wednesday.

website_content.content:
**CHICAGO (CBS/AP)** — Former President Donald Trump's appearance before the National Association of Black Journalists in Chicago quickly turned hostile on Wednesday, even before the event officially began over an hour behind schedule.
Trump blamed issues with the audio equipment for the delayed start of a Q&A session  the National Association of Black Journalists Annual Convention & Career Fair in Chicago Wednesday afternoon.
The event itself began with a series of questions that Trump characterized as a "very rude introduction," sparring with interviewer Rachel Scott of ABC News.
"You have used words like 'animal' and 'rabid' to describe Black district attorneys. You've attacked Black journalists—calling them a loser, saying the questions that they asked are quote, 'stupid' and 'racist,'" Scott said. "Why should Black voters trust you after you have used language like that?"
"I don't think I've ever been asked a question in such a horrible manner—first question," Trump said in response. "You don't even say, 'Hello, how are you?'"
Trump also seemingly accused event organizers of holding up the start of the event, which was scheduled to begin at noon in Chicago, but didn't kick off until after 1 p.m.
 by  on 
"I think it's disgraceful that I came here in good spirit. I love the Black population of this country, I've done so much for the Black population of this country," Trump said.
Trump,...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: CBS News is one of the major American television networks with a longstanding reputation for journalistic credibility. It has a professional editorial staff and a rigorous fact-checking process. The network is recognized for its accurate and timely reporting, although, like all media outlets, it may face bias accusations from various political perspectives. Overall, it remains a reliable source of news.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence relates to Trump’s recent engagements with Black journalists but does not mention any incidents of violence involving Trump supporters or protesters. It does not address the claim about a black Trump supporter being shot and does not add relevant information.

metatags.og:description: Findings from Armed Conflict Location and Event Data raise concerns about continued violence during and after election day
metatags.twitter:creator: @loisbeckett
metatags.og:title: At least 25 Americans were killed during protests and political unrest in 2020
metatags.article:author: https://www.theguardian.com/profile/lois-beckett

website_content.content:
At least 11 Americans have been killed while participating in political demonstrations this year and another 14 have died in other incidents linked to political unrest, according to new data from a non-profit monitoring political unrest in the United States.
Nine of the people killed during protests were demonstrators taking part in Black Lives Matter protests. Two were conservatives killed after pro-Trump “patriot rallies”. All but one were killed by fellow citizens.
The new data highlights the danger of the presence of guns during politically charged protests, and raises concerns about continued violence during and after election day, when many Americans anticipate delays, confusion and protests before the winner of the presidential race is confirmed.
Violence at US protests
-----------------------
The  on fatalities and violence at American protests comes from a database created by the Armed Conflict Location and Event Data project (), a non-profit, working in collaboration with a group of researchers at Princeton.
ACLED, a widely cited source for data on civilian casualties in Yemen, has been a non-partisan monitor of protests and violence in the Middle East, Asia, Europe and Latin America, and launched its US Crisis Monitor in July, citing concerns over .
ACLED found that the  of the  Black Lives Matter demonstrations that took place across the US after the killing of George Floyd have been peaceful. News reports at the height of demonstrations over Floyd’s killing cited  deaths in connection with protests, but many of those turned out to be  carried out in the vicinity of protests, rather than directly related to the demonstrations themselves, the researchers concluded. ACLED’s dataset only...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The Guardian is a well-established British news organization known for comprehensive coverage and investigative reporting. It has a reputation for high-quality journalism, though in recent years some critics have pointed out a perceived bias in its reporting. Overall, it is considered credible but may have ideological slants that can influence its news coverage.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence discusses deaths during protests, including conservatives killed after Trump-related rallies. It indicates that incidents involving violence against Trump supporters have occurred, but it does not confirm any incident specifically in Chicago relating to a black Trump supporter being killed, thus making it moderately relevant.

metatags.twitter:title: In Kenosha, Trump praises police after controversial remarks about violence
metatags.og:title: In Kenosha, Trump praises police after controversial remarks about violence
metatags.og:description: President Trump visited Kenosha, Wisconsin, a day after defending a supporter who allegedly killed two people there. Kenosha erupted in outrage after police shot Jacob Blake, who is Black, in the back, reportedly leaving him paralyzed. During Trump's visit, which numerous city officials opposed, he toured burned-out buildings, praised police and denounced local Democrats. Yamiche Alcindor reports.

In Kenosha, Trump praises police after controversial remarks about violence
===========================================================================
Sep 1, 2020 6:50 PM EDT
]
By — 
Leave a comment
399comments
Share
*   Copy URL
    https://www.pbs.org/newshour/show/in-kenosha-trump-praises-police-after-controversial-remarks-about-violence
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
President Trump visited Kenosha, Wisconsin, a day after defending a supporter who allegedly killed two people there. Kenosha erupted in outrage after police shot Jacob Blake, who is Black, in the back, reportedly leaving him paralyzed. During Trump's visit, which numerous city officials opposed, he toured burned-out buildings, praised police and denounced local Democrats. Yamiche Alcindor reports.
Read the Full Transcript
------------------------
_Notice: Transcripts are machine and human generated and lightly edited for accuracy. They may contain errors._
*   **Judy Woodruff:**
    Race, justice, law and order. We face a critical moment in America.
    As Yamiche Alcindor reports, protests in the streets are a key issue at the ballot box, and Wisconsin was at the center of attention today.
*   **Yamiche Alcindor:**
    One day after comparing police shootings to golfing and defending a Trump supporter who allegedly killed two people, President Trump came to Kenosha, Wisconsin.
    The city is still...[Content truncated]

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence mentions Trump defending a supporter involved in violence but does not confirm that a black Trump supporter was shot and killed by protesters in Chicago. It is somewhat relevant as it discusses the surrounding protests and violence but lacks specificity on the claim in question.

Fact-checking Trump’s many falsehoods during NABJ interview - The Washington Post
===============
Advertisement
Democracy Dies in Darkness
Trump issues many falsehoods at Black journalists’ convention
=============================================================
The former president falsely claims nobody was charged for deaths in Black Lives Matter protests.
6 min
4172
Sorry, a summary is not available for this article at this time. Please try again later.
!
Donald Trump and Rachel Scott, senior congressional correspondent for ABC News, at the National Association of Black Journalists convention in Chicago on July 31. (Joel Angel Juarez for The Washington Post)
!
Analysis by 
Updated July 31, 2024 at 8:09 p.m. EDT|Published July 31, 2024 at 7:42 p.m. EDT
_“You know, nobody died that day, you do know that? But people died in Seattle. Nobody died, but people died in Minneapolis. You know, people died in Minneapolis, and nothing happens. And nobody ever talks and nothing happens to those people. But you went after the J6 people with a vengeance.”_
**— , in a conversation at the National Association of Black Journalists convention in Chicago, July 31**
In his half-hour sit-down with three journalists at NABJ, the former president and Republican presidential nominee unleashed his usual litany of falsehoods, ranging from a phony story about the ex-governor of Virginia executing a baby after birth to an absurd claim that he “saved” historically Black colleges and universities. To a Black audience, he yet again bragged he did more for Black people than any president since Abraham Lincoln — earning the instant rejoinder (which he ignored) from ABC News’s Rachel Scott: “Better than President Johnson, who signed the Voting Rights Act?”
Advertisement
Story continues below advertisement
Rather than...[Content truncated]

Nevertheless, it remains a credible source that exposes misinformation and holds power accountable.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence discusses false claims made by Trump regarding deaths in protests, including the assertion that no one was charged for deaths during Black Lives Matter protests. While it does touch upon the theme of violence surrounding protests, it does not directly verify the claim in question and is thus less relevant.

website_content.content:
### **_Commentary: Trump, militias, and the long history of voter intimidation and violence in the Midwest  
_**
_By Ryan Schnurr  
_
On May 3, 1876, residents of Indianapolis, Indiana went to the polls. It was a special election day for city council. The Fifteenth Amendment, ratified six years earlier, held that citizens could not be denied the vote based on “race, color, or previous condition of servitude,” so Black men participated. Soon, news came out of the sixth ward that Black voters there were being harassed and attacked. , Black residents from the fourth ward went to investigate and were met by a mob of white residents and police, who “converged on the Black citizens.” One Black man was stabbed and eventually died; others were shot or beaten.
In the weeks leading up to the election, Democrats—who were, at the time, the party least aligned with Black interests—had made what the _Chicago Daily Tribune_ called “incendiary remarks” about Black people exercising their rights on election day. They also  that Republicans had “inflated their voting base by importing blacks right before the election and that these black voters intended to cast multiple ballots.” Such allegations offered an apparent justification for efforts to suppress the vote through intimidation and violence. And, according to a contemporary newspaper, they worked: “One man was knocked down...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Belt Magazine is a regional publication focused on the Midwest and often emphasizes cultural stories and community issues. While it can offer insightful reporting on local matters, it lacks the broad national reach or historical track record of larger mainstream institutions. Its niche focus can be insightful but may lead to less comprehensive news coverage.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This commentary discusses voter intimidation and violence in the context of Trump but does not mention a specific incident involving a black Trump supporter in Chicago. As it does not provide direct evidence related to the claim, it scores low in relevance.

metatags.title: Trump rally in Kenosha among final stops in president's 2020 election campaign
metatags.og:description: President Donald Trump's rally in Kenosha, one of the closing stops of his 2020 election campaign, comes two months after street violence shook the lakeside city.
metatags.twitter:creator: @abc7chicago
metatags.twitter:title: Trump rally in Kenosha among final stops in president's 2020 election campaign
metatags.og:title: Trump rally in Kenosha among final stops in president's 2020 election campaign
metatags.twitter:description: President Donald Trump's rally in Kenosha, one of the closing stops of his 2020 election campaign, comes two months after street violence shook the lakeside city.

website_content.content:
KENOSHA, Wis. -- President Donald Trump is making one of his last election campaign stops Kenosha, Wisconsin, the lakeside city that's seen much unrest and destruction this summer in a county he won by less than 300 votes and a city he didn't win at all in 2016.
On the ground in Wisconsin Monday night, the president said a Supreme Court decision to allow mail in votes in Pennsylvania to be counted after Election Day could lead to violence.
"It is a horrendous decision for our country," President Trump said. "It's a mistake. It allows cheating. It allows cheating at a very high level and very easy cheating too."
In the waning hours of his second campaign, Trump asked Kenosha voters to help give him another term in the White House.
Kenosha voters squeaked out a win for then-candidate Trump by the narrowest margin of any county in a state that helped make him President Trump.
A second victory here in Wisconsin would also be a surprise. the latest ABC News/Washington Post poll released last week has Trump trailing former Vice President Biden by 17 points in the state of Wisconsin.
Some people in the area were excited for the president's visit, and eager for a second term.
"Our economy has been great the last four years," said Amy Smith, owner of Jerry Smith Produce and Pumpkin Farm. "That's huge. He loves America more than anybody, any other president."
But in few places in the country is COVID-19 as rampant as in Wisconsin, where case numbers are surging. And not everyone attending the rally Monday night is a Wisconsonite.
"I think the whole COVID thing is a little overblown," said Michael Robinson, a Trump supporter who traveled from Indiana. "Like Trump has been saying recently, if you want to wear a mask, if you don't I shouldn't' be forced to."
The state of the pandemic in Wisconsin is helping catapult early voting and vote by mail returns; 59 percent of registered voters in Kenosha County have already cast their ballot.
Early voters waiting in line at Kenosha's municipal offices couldn't miss...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: ABC 7 News is a local affiliate of the ABC network and provides local coverage in Chicago. While it covers breaking news effectively and has a good reputation for local news, it might sometimes follow sensational trends which can reduce its overall credibility compared to more robust national news organizations. However, it generally provides reliable information.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This piece discusses the political atmosphere in Kenosha related to Trump’s campaign but does not provide evidence of violence against a black Trump supporter in Chicago. It offers some context about Trump's influence in protests but does not confirm the claim’s specifics.
